title: What kind of math basis is needed to understand probability? - Quora

response.answer_text: That depends on what you mean by “understand probability”. At the most basic level, you’d only need to understand fractions the way you were probably taught them in elementary school. At the highest level on a statistical side, you’d need to learn measure theory, which would require quite a lot of math indeed (I think this would ordinarily be taught in an upper level elective in an undergraduate math department, or possibly in graduate level math or statistics). And there are all sorts of levels in between. Getting a real grip on the differences between Bayesian and frequentist uses of the term probably requires at least some familiarity with integrals. And, in addition, there are a lot of tricky philosophical issues that don’t exactly require math, but do sort of depend on understanding some mathematical constructs.

A lot of basic probability theory can be mastered with just a bit of high school algebra and set theory. The exception is continuous random variables which require a working knowledge of calculus. When you start combining different random variables together, the mathematics can become quite hairy.
